data: The collection in the "Casina degli Inglesi" consists of 20 inscriptions, 1 statue, two busts, a few mosaics, a 2nd C AD marble sarcophagus and some modern art
Six lines of Latin, filling the surviving face. The first line starts closer to the left margin of the stone.
Very regular letters, with serifs and a moderately wide module. R and B are closed, P is slightly open. A has a horizontal serif across the top. Interpuncts are irregular, sometimes triangular.
If the proposed reconstruction is correct, as a dedication to Caracalla, dates to 211-217 CE
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana; photo L. Campagna 2005-11-23
End of two lines of Latin letters, of which the first much larger.
Large, fairly wide, v-cut letters,with long serifs.
Manganaro proposed restoring as a dedication to Commodus, but the reading is against this; it has the form of an honorific, however, likely imperial
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana; photo L. Campagna 2004-11-16

Manganaro, 1989, Iscrizioni Latine nuove e vecchie della Sicilia
Thinly incised letters, with terminal points or minimal serifs. E with upward sloping crossbars, V left-ward leaning. A moderately narrow module.

Two lines of large Latin letters
Tall, deeply cut letters with simple serifs and three-pointed serifs.

Block of marmor Luculleum bearing quarry inscription

Two single lines of text, one on the left and one on the right side. Both texts run left to right, and so the text on the left runs from the rear of the stone to the front, while the text on the right runs from the front to the back. The text on the left is missing the opening letters, having been inscribed prior to the removal of the 'step' from the rear of the stone. The text on the right appears to be essentially intact.
Explicitly dated to the consulship of 108 CE

The text preserved belongs to a single column of text, with the sixth fragment belonging to the same column as the others, and containing the end of the column of text; at least one further column must have stood to the right originally.
After 8 BCE (assuming that it was produced at the same time as the associated calendar), and probably Augustan rather than Tiberian (so Ruck), so between 8 BCE and 14 CE.

Although earlier studies dated to before 19 BCE, Ruck demonstrates that the calendar must be after 8 BCE (Augustus replaces Sextilis), and probably Augustan rather than Tiberian.

Three partially preserved letters of a single line of monumental letters
Neat, broad v-cut letters, with well-formed serifs; P is slightly open.

Four lines of Latin letters, with guidelines to top and bottom of each line. Line 4 smaller than the first three.
Very neat and regular v-cut letters with a broad square module and elegant serifs. M has vertical first and last, with full-length mid-strokes; elegant hedera in line 4 as word-divider.
Fragment of a Latin text containing numerals
Remains of three lines of Latin letters of equal height, vacat below.
Latin capitals, long serifs and a deep triangular interpunct.

Text over four lines, lines 1, 3, 4 share the same left margin, line 2 begins further to the left.
Letters with a fluid / curving stroke, extensions to strokes and/or serirfs, R is open.
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana; photo L. Campagna, 2004-12-30

The text is inscribed on three faces, the precise organisation of which remains a question of discussion. Battistoni 2020 and 2011, after Bormann, offers the most plausible and complete reconstruction, followed here: Section A in two columns on face I (left face for the viewer), continuing upper left on face III (central face for the viewer); Section B in a single column on face II (right face for the viewer); Section C, top of face III, followed by a large lacuna; Section D, lower left of face III; Section E.i, traces top right of face III, followed by a large lacuna; section E.ii, lower right of face III.
Photo J. Prag, courtesy Parco archeologico di Naxos

Dedication of an altar for Hestia
six lines of Greek letters in a recessed field 23 cm high, with consistent left margin, uneven right margin, at times rather compressed on the right (e.g. line 5), and vacat below.

Neat and regular letters without serfis (but slight terminal marks to the strokes). Alpha with straight cross bar, beta with equal closed eyes, epsilon with short middle stroke, theta slightly ovoid with detached middle bar, kappa with short arms, mu with almost vertical first and last, and three-quarter mid-strokes; xsi with three horizontal bars, lowest the longest; omicron smaller and mid-line, pi with equal vertical strokes; rho rounded closed eye; sigma with very slightly open top and bottom strokes; phi with round eye, slightly extended vertical; omega mostly circular, slightly open, short horizontal feet.
3rd or 2nd century BCE, lettering of the early-mid Hellenistic.
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana; photo J. Prag 22-03-2017
Sfameni Gasparro, 1973, I culti orientali in Sicilia
Kaibel, 1878, Epigrammata graeca ex lapidibus conlecta
Sfameni Gasparro, 2000, Les cultes isiaques en Sicile
Muscolino, 2014, San Pancrazio e il Falcone. culti antichi e recenti da Taormina a Naxos. I.
dedication of an altar for hestia
Statue base in honour of Olympis Mestos

The inscription is set out over four lines on the front face of the block on its upper half. The text is roughly centred, lines 1-3 filling the face, line 4 a single word approximately centered. Spacing between words is apparent and increases significantly in line 3.

The letters are regular and with terminal points rather than serfis, and are inscribed in parts in what is almost a punch style, rather than a chiselled groove. Alpha has broken bar; epsilon has mostly equal legnth cross-bars; theta has a full-width cross bar; kappa has full length bars; mu has vertical first and last, three-quarter length mid-strokes; omicron is full-size; pi has eual length verticals; rho has fair-sized closed eye; sigma has horizontal top and bottom strokes; omega is rhomboid and closed.
Later Hellenistic, later second or first century BCE?
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana; photo 2009-10-06

Gentile, 2002, Olumpis Olumpios ed IG, XIV, 434
statue base in honour of olympis mestos
Inscribed statue base for Gaius Claudius Marcellus

The text is laid out over two lines, off-centre, with the first line set 2-3 letters in from the left margin, the second, longer line c.4 letters in from the left margin. A large single letter appears to sit centrally to the face of the block immediately below lines 1-2.

Simply carved letters, without serifs, showing very slight curvature on the longer strokes (e.g. on alpha). The channels are not always smoothly cut, but rather staccato. Alpha with straight bar; epsilon with shorter middle bar; kappa with medium length arms (not full length); mu with vertical first and last, middle strokes to half height; omicron full size; sigma with horizontal top and bottom strokes.
inscribed statue base for gaius claudius marcellus
Three lines of Greek letters filling the stone from the top
Crude letters, often cut with a shallow square channel. Quadrate and lunate epsilon.
rhomboid theta and omega, quadrate lunate sigma.

Note the lack of serifs and the homogeneity in size of the round letters compared to the others (omicron).
The likely appearance of the formula "devotus numini maiestatique eius" belongs to the period between the early third and late fourth century CE
if this is Greek, then the serifs suggest and imperial period date

Assuming Manganaro's hypothesis that this side is secondary is correct, this text post-dates 96 CE. Attribution to Lucilla would date this to 164-168/9 CE.
